ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to more thoughtfully engage with global literature and improved my close-reading skills

This was a great class for learning to think critically about texts in their geographical and historical contexts. We read a fantastic selection of books and engaged with primary sources in our papers.
Writing about and close reading world literature.

Beyond the normal development of writing and reading that comes with most English WR classes, 128 particularly with Professor Richards helped me discover the importance of intersectionality when analyzing and thinking about racial identity and gender identity. Considering these two things leads to more productive outcomes than just one identity in a vacuum.
Through this course, we learned to analyze literature from the perspective of African and Eastern-Asian contexts through  the lens of colonization
Understanding of topics in world literature, understanding of particular regional literatures

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The books in this class are AMAZING! Lots of reading, about a book a week. But a required course for English majors. Such a difference from the old white guys we're used to reading as English majors. Even better if the peers in your seminar are engaging, makes for a better discussion. Only 3 papers too!

The course is fantastic. The readings are diverse yet fit together seamlessly with the larger narrative of the course and are all really interesting. The assignments ramp up in length as the semester goes on which provides a very natural progression to learn the ropes of essay writing at the college level. No weaknesses!

Such a strong class. I felt like the syllabus was balanced well and never felt too overwhelming. I was in a relatively small class (7 people), which I think was a huge strength. In a larger group the discussion might not have been so exciting and engaging.
Not a lot of feedback on writing, but interesting text and Prof. Richards fostered interesting discussions

Strengths was the amazing selection of works, particularly The God of Small Things and Waiting for the Barbarians, as well as Professor Richards who was probably the most understanding, sympathetic, and empathetic professor I have yet had. She didn't overload us with work though we still got much done and engaged with a dozen or so works in just a semester.
The texts were very interesting and unique. There was a large scope of subjects to discuss and the professor did a good job of providing context for our texts. Cons would include so very dense texts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small size of the class made it so the seminar could be conducted pretty seamlessly, despite being virtual. The group presentations were also a great way to engage with fellow students outside of normal class time

Jill Richards did a fantastic job facilitating a virtual class. She combined online and offline activities, occasionally trading out zoom class for asynchronous work. There was a lot of low-pressure discussion in class, which allowed everyone to get out ideas and feel less intimidated by the on-camera nature of the class.
The online seminar was great and very flexible

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! If you like reading (a lot) and are bored of the super westernized curriculum of a lot of other classes, this is a great option. The authors were interesting and the paper writing wasn't too difficult.

Absolutely! The texts in the course are fascinating and the writing assignments have a natural progression to them so putting it all together in the final paper is very manageable. Out of the foundational English courses, this has been my favorite so far
Yes!! This was a great class with a really well crafted syllabus. The workload was interesting and not overwhelming, and the in-class discussions were always idea-provoking.
Yes. Required for English major but a good class in itself.

Yes. World literatures in English are so important, and it's terrible how English majors and other students can go their entire college careers without taking anything except the white western canon and ignore all of these, to be completely frank, superior works of written English that come from non-American or European-native authors.
I would recommend this course to another student especially if they're interested in English. The class will definitely open your mind to new perspectives.
Core course of English major.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Asynchronous assignments which included independent discussion then discussion replies, and independent research into archival documents
